The better results found for those students taking part in Creative
across all three subjects may suggest that participation in structured arts projects leads to a
general improvement in attainment rather than something subject specific.
t is difficult, however, to decipher the exact mechanism that produced
attainment, as the description of the Creative Partnership
scheme is not very detailed and it
would appear that there was considerable scope for different activities under the umbrella of
or may not be an important element of the
3.3 Does participation in structured arts activities improve early literacy skills?
Five Medium quality studies conducted in the USA measured the impact of arts participation
s early literacy skills (Gromko, 2005; McMahon et al., 2003;
2009; Register, 2004; Standley and Hughes, 1997). The studies used different
instruments to measure different aspects of early literacy. The studies by McM
(2003) and by Piro and Ortiz (2009) focused on children of primary school age (grade
1 and 2), while the remaining three studies considered impacts on younger children.
One study evaluated the effectiveness of an arts
(McMahon et al., 2003). Piro and Ortiz (2009) evaluated keyboard
The remaining three studies evaluated multi
incorporated activities such as singing, playing instrumen
Register, 2004; Standley and Hughes, 1997). In all five studies, the main goal of the
intervention was to enhance early literacy skills (four studies focused on reading and one on
writing). Each individual lesson therefore in
volved the fusion of both arts
(music or dance) and literacy activities. An example of how these two different types of
activities were combined in a single initiative is provided in Box
Box 3.2: Evaluation of Basic Reading Through D
The 'Basic Reading Through Dance' programme was a curriculum
intervention developed by Whirlwind, a not
profit organisation in the US. This arts
based educational programme had one general goal: to improve stud
reading skills. Each session in the programme required students to use their bodies
to physically represent the alphabet symbols for various sounds in the English
language, as well as combinations of sounds. To physically represent each sound,
students had to (a) visualise the appropriate symbols (letters) for spoken sounds and
then (b) recreate these images physically using their bodies. Three trained artists
implemented the programme, which was delivered in schools over 10 weeks (twice a
The study used an unmatched comparison group design and participants in this study
grade students from Chicago public schools. The study examined the
effects of the programme on reading skills, as assessed by different s
These five studies appear to evaluate similar interventions in the same age group.
the instruments used vary, as does the vocabulary used by the study authors to describe the
outcomes are all measures of a global phenomenon of
the different instruments/outcomes are measuring the same or different sub
Whilst it is possible to combine subsets of the studies that are not statistically heterogeneous
we do not find any of such combinations pl
reported a pooled effect size for this group of studies.
vote counting indicates that ten outcomes from five studies found that those students who
did not participate, and three outcomes were inconclusive.
